q: What is a blood transfusion?
a: A blood transfusion is when you're given blood from someone else (a donor). It's a very safe procedure that can be lifesaving.

q: When might a blood transfusion be needed?
a: A blood transfusion may be needed if you have a shortage of red blood cells. This may be because your body's not making enough red blood cells or because you have lost blood.

q: What happens during a blood transfusion?
a: Before having a blood transfusion, the procedure will be explained to you and you'll be asked to sign a consent form. A sample of your blood will also be taken to check your blood group. You'll be given blood that's safe for someone with your blood group.

q: How long does a blood transfusion usually take?
a: It can take up to 4 hours to receive 1 bag of blood, but it's usually quicker than this. You can normally go home soon after, unless you're seriously unwell or need a lot of blood.

q: What are the potential risks of a blood transfusion?
a: Blood transfusions are common and very safe procedures. All donor blood is checked for infections. However, there's a very small risk of complications such as allergic reactions or problems with the heart, lungs, or immune system.

q: Are there any alternatives to a blood transfusion?
a: A blood transfusion will only be recommended if it's needed and other treatments will not help. Alternative treatments may include medications to lower the risk of bleeding or to boost the number of red blood cells.

q: Can I give blood after having a blood transfusion?
a: Currently, you cannot give blood if you had a blood transfusion after 1 January 1980. This is a precautionary measure to reduce the risk of variant CJD being passed on by donors.
